metadata.title: Nano-MgO reinforced chitosan nanocomposites for high performance packaging applications with improved mechanical, thermal and barrier properties
authors: M. M. M. G. P. G. Mantilaka

sections.text:
Chitosan nanocomposite thin films were fabricated by incorporating MgO nanoparticles to significantly improve its physical properties for potential packaging applications. A novel insitu method was developed to synthesise spherical shaped MgO nanoparticles by heat-
treating magnesium carbonate/poly (methyl methacrylate) (PMMA) composite precursor. Optimum mechanical properties of chitosan composites were yielded at 5 (w/w %) of MgO concentration, where tensile stress and elastic modulus significantly improved by 86 % and 38 %, respectively, compared to those of pure chitosan films. These improvements are due to the interaction of hydroxyl and amine groups of chitosan with MgO as confirmed by FTIR spectroscopy. Fracture surface morphology indicated the interplay between MgO dispersion and aggregation on the mechanical properties at different MgO concentrations. Furthermore, the chitosan/MgO nanocomposites displayed remarkable thermal stability, flame retardant properties (satisfied V0 rating according to UL-94 standards), UV shielding and moisture barrier properties, which could certainly add value to the packaging material.
Keywords: Chitosan; nano-magnesium oxide; thin films; mechanical properties; thermal stability

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Bio-polymeric materials have attracted a great deal of attention recently due to the environmental concerns of consumption of petrochemical based materials in the packaging industry. Chitosan is an alternatives to replace “environment threatening” materials due to its unique properties such as non-toxicity, good biocompatibility, biodegradability, and antimicrobial and anti-fungal properties (Aider, 2010; van den Broek, Knoop, Kappen, & Boeriu, 2015). Chitosan is a deacetylated product of chitin, derived from crab and shrimp shells. It is a polysaccharide with a linear polymer of β-(1,4)-2-acetamido-2-deoxy-dglucopyranose units. The polycationic nature of chitosan can neutralize the bacterial metabolism (antimicrobial property), making it a good material to be used in the food packaging industry (Leceta, Guerrero, Ibarburu, Dueñas, & de la Caba, 2013). Furthermore, chitosan is used as a scaffolding material in tissue engineering applications (artificial tissue, wound dressing, etc.) since it facilitates a favourable environment for cell growth (Croisier & Jérôme, 2013). Chitosan membranes have also been used in filtration applications to remove heavy metal ions (Kadib, Bousmina, & Brunel, 2014; Varma, Deshpande, & Kennedy, 2004; Wan Ngah, Endud, & Mayanar, 2002). Moreover, different forms of chitosan (nano and microparticles, etc.) have been used for many other applications such as drug delivery (El Kadib & Bousmina, 2012; García-González, Alnaief, & Smirnova, 2011), catalysis (El
Kadib, 2015; Guibal, 2005) and polymer reinforcements (Wijesena et al., 2015; Wijesena, Tissera, Perera, & de Silva, 2014). Although chitosan membranes/films exhibit remarkable properties, poor mechanical, thermal and barrier properties restrict its usage in a wider range of potential applications (Jayakumar, Menon, Manzoor, Nair, & Tamura, 2010). Hence, chitosan has been reinforced by preparing nanocomposites with various nano-fillers such as nano-clay (montmorillonite, halloysite, sepiolite) (R. De Silva, Pasbakhsh, Goh, Chai, & Ismail, 2013; Frindy et al., 2016; Paluszkiewicz, Stodolak, Hasik, & Blazewicz, 2011), hydroxyapatite (Pighinelli & Kucharska, 2013), carbon nanotubes (Yan, Wu, Ding, & Li, 2016) and metal oxides/substances (Li, Deng, Deng, Liu, & Li, 2010; Youssef, Abou-Yousef, El-Sayed, & Kamel, 2015). Of these nano-fillers, nano-scaled metal oxides such as ZnO, Fe3O4 and TiO2 add more value to chitosan nanocomposites due to their synergetic properties including antimicrobial, UV-blocking and magnetic properties in addition to their reinforcing ability (Cesano, Fenoglio, Carlos, & Nisticò, 2015; Esfahani, Tyler, Stretz, & Wells, 2015; Im, Oh, Nathanael, & Jang, 2015). Youssef et al. reported that ZnO and Ag incorporated chitosan films improved the tensile strength of the material by 58% and 52%, respectively compared to that of pure chitosan films, while exhibiting significantly improved antimicrobial activity (Youssef et al., 2015). Although a number of studies have been conducted on chitosan nanocomposites with different types of metal oxides, very limited work has been carried out on MgO as a nano-filler to reinforce chitosan. MgO is an extensively used metal oxide which can easily be synthesized using economical methods with low-cost raw materials such as brines, magnesium salts and magnesium bearing minerals including dolomite and magnesite (Mantilaka, Pitawala, Karunaratne, & Rajapakse, 2014). MgO nanoparticles possess many interesting features including antimicrobial activity, thermal and electrical insulation, non-toxicity, good biocompatibility, large surface area-tovolume ratio, UV blocking ability and photocatalytic activity (Salehifar, Zarghami, & Ramezani, 2016; Sundararaman & Song, 2014; Wetteland, Nguyen, & Liu). As a result, the nanometre sized MgO has been in great demand in recent years with a broad-range of applications such as a bactericide, ceramic material, catalyst, material for toxic waste remediation, insulator and refractory material (Mantilaka et al., 2014; Salehifar et al., 2016; Sundararaman & Song, 2014; Wetteland et al.). MgO nanoparticles are produced through heat treatment of various precursors such as nanometre sized magnesium hydroxide, magnesium carbonates and their composites. Precursor nanoparticles can be kept in the nanometre scale using polymers and surfactants (Mantilaka et al., 2014; Simanjuntak, Lim,
Ahn, Kim, & Lee, 2014). These surfactant and polymer chains prevent aggregation of precursor particles (Mantilaka et al., 2014). Furthermore, the morphology and the size of the final MgO product depend on the polymer or surfactant used in the precursor material (Meshkani & Rezaei, 2010; Simanjuntak et al., 2014). To the best of our knowledge this method on synthesis of MgO nanoparticles through calcination of PMMA/MgCO3 has not been published before. A similar method has been used to synthesize PMMA/CaCO3 nanoparticles (Mantilaka, Karunaratne, Rajapakse, & Pitawala, 2013). Zhao et al. synthesised whiskers-like MgO nanoparticles and used them as a nano-filler to reinforce polylactic acid, and reported that the elastic modulus and tensile strength increased by 78% and 17%, respectively, with the addiction of 1 wt% of functionalized MgO (Zhao, Liu, You, & Chen, 2016). MgO has also been used as a UV-shielding filler in electrospun poly acrylonitrile fibrous mats (Dadvar, Tavanai, & Morshed, 2011). Rajendran et al. fabricated cotton/MgO nanocomposite fabrics with enhanced thermal stability, fire retardancy and antimicrobial properties (Rajendran, Dhineshbabu, Kanna, & Kaler, 2014). In another study, the enhancement of the thermo-mechanical properties of chitosan nanocomposites with clove oil and MgO was investigated (Sanuja, Agalya, & Umapathy, 2014), but the influence of MgO on the physical properties of chitosan as well as the filler-matrix interfacial interaction were not systematically explored. In this study, the physico-chemical characteristics of chitosan/MgO nanocomposite films were systematically investigated. Spherical MgO nanoparticles were successfully synthesised by heat treating a novel magnesium carbonate/poly(methyl methacrylate) (PMMA) composite precursor for the first time. Chitosan/MgO nanocomposites films were prepared by a solution casting technique. The influence of nano-MgO on mechanical, thermal, morphological and barrier properties of chitosan films were systematically studied. The fabricated chitosan/MgO nanocomposite film with enhanced physico-chemical properties can certainly be used as a potential packaging material to preserve the quality of food products.

sections.heading: 2.1. Materials
sections.text: High molecular weight chitosan flakes (1.42 × 106 according to Mark-Houwink equation) with a deactylation percentage of 75% was purchased from HiMedia Laboratories Pvt. Ltd. Methyl methacrylate (MMA) (99% purity), sodium persulfate (99% purity), anhydrous sodium carbonate (99.8% purity), magnesium chloride hexahydrate (99% purity), sodium hydroxide pellets and analytical grade acetic acid were purchased from Sigma–Aldrich, USA.

sections.heading: 2.2. Synthesis of MgO through PMMA/MgCO3 composite precursor
sections.text: 1 M sodium carbonate (100 mL) solution was placed in a 250 mL three neck round bottomed flask. Sodium persulfate (1 g) initiator was dissolved in the sodium carbonate solution. 10 mL of fresh MMA monomer and 1 M magnesium chloride (100 mL) solution were added dropwise, simultaneously, to the reaction mixture while stirring and maintaining the temperature of the reaction mixture at 80 °C. The reaction mixture was further stirred for 2 h. The obtained PMMA/MgCO3 composite precursor particles were collected by centrifuging and were washed with hot water for 3 times in order to remove impurities. The PMMA/MgCO3 composite precursor was heated at 600 ᴼC for 3 h to produce MgO nanoparticles (hereafter MgO nanoparticles are referred as MgO).

sections.heading: 2.3. Fabrication of chitosan/MgO nanocomposite films
sections.text: 1g of chitosan was dissolved in 100 mL of 1% (w/v) acetic acid and stirred (magnetic stirring, 500 rpm) for 12 h. Resultant solution was filtered through a 0.5 mm sieve and corresponding amount of MgO was added under vigorous stirring to prepare 5 and 10 (w/w %) compositions. The resultant solution was stirred for 24 h at 1000 rpm, followed by an ultrasound treatment (amplitude of 80, 1:1 pulse ratio) for 10 mins to achieve a homogenous dispersion of MgO. Thereafter, 20 g from the resultant chitosan-MgO solution was poured into glass petri dishes (8 cm) and dried at 50 ˚C for 4 days in vacuum oven to evaporate the solvent. Chitosan/MgO nanocomposite films were peeled off from the petri dishes after neutralizing the left over acetic acid in the films by adding 5 ml of 1M NaOH and rinsed with distilled water. Fabricated nanocomposite films were stored in a desiccator (at 25 °C and 50% relative humidity (RH)) for 48h prior to further testing.

sections.heading: 2.4. Physico-chemical characterization of chitosan nanocomposites and MgO
2.4.1. X-ray diffraction
sections.text:
Crystallographic structure of synthesised MgO-PMMA and MgO nanoparticles were
analysed using X-ray diffractometer (Bruker, Focus D8). The CuK radiation source was operated at a 40 kV power and 40 mA current, and data collected within 10 - 70˚ of diffraction angle (2θ). Average crystallite size of MgO nanoparticles was calculated by applying the Debye-Scherrer equation to the major XRD peak of MgO, as given in Equation 1.

sections.heading: D = 0.89λ/βcosθ (Eq 2)
sections.text: where, λ is the X-ray wavelength of the Cu Kα radiation (=1.54 Å), β is the full width at half maximum of the XRD peak and θ is the angle of diffraction.

sections.heading: 2.4.2. Tensile test
sections.text: Mechanical properties (ultimate tensile strength (σ) [in these results σ and yield stress deemed to be the same], elastic modulus (E) and elongation at break (ɛ)) of chitosan/MgO nanocomposites were measured (using Instron Tensile test rig) according to the ASTM D88202 with a strain rate of 5 mm/min. Thickness of each film was measured using digital micrometer screw-gauge (Mitutoyo, 0.001 mm resolution) prior to testing. One-way analysis of variance (one-way ANOVA) was implemented by “Tukey’s Post-Hoc test” using commercial software (OriginPro 8) to investigate the statistical significant difference between the means of σ, E and ɛ with respect to MgO concentration.

sections.heading: 2.4.3. Morphological analysis
sections.text: The morphologies of the tensile fracture surface of chitosan/MgO nanocomposites as well as the synthesised MgO nanoparticles were investigated using a field-emission scanning electron microscope (FE-SEM) (Hitachi SU6600). To prevent electrostatic charging during observation, the samples were coated with a thin layer of gold.

sections.heading: 2.4.4. Thermal properties
sections.text: The thermal decomposition temperature of chitosan nanocomposites were determined by thermo gravimetric analysis (TGA) (STD Q600) from 25 to 800 ˚C at a heating rate of 10 ˚C/min in nitrogen medium. Flame retardancy of chitosan nanocomposites were evaluated by glow-wire test (model 8806GWT) according to U-94 standard (ISO 13943) and the burn rate (time taken to thermally degrade a unit length of the material) was determined.

sections.heading: 2.4.5. Chemical properties
sections.text:
Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy (Bruker Vertex 80) was conducted to identify the filler-matrix interfacial interaction and chemical homogeneity of chitosan/MgO
nanocomposites. All spectra were obtained within 500 – 4000 cm-1 with 32 scans per measurement at 0.4 cm-1 resolution.

sections.heading: 2.4.6. UV shielding properties
sections.text: UV absorption spectra of chitosan/MgO nanocomposites were collected within 200 - 400 nm of wavelength using UV-Visible Spectrophotometer (Shimadzu UV-3600).

sections.heading: 2.4.7 Water vapour transmission rate (WVTR)
sections.text: WVTR of chitosan nanocomposites was determined by the gravimetric method according to the ASTM E96. Data was collected hourly for 24h at 30 °C and 50% RH. WVTR was calculated using Equation 2, where, G, t and A denote to weight change, time and crosssection area, respectively. Parameter G/t was obtained from the slope of weigh change vs time plot. WVTR = G/tA (Eq. 2)

sections.heading: 3.1 Characteristics of MgO nanoparticles prepared through PMMA/MgCO3 precursor
sections.text:
XRD pattern of PMMA/MgCO3 composite precursor particles (Fig. 1 (a)) is composed of peaks at 2θ values of 13.75ᴼ, 15.24ᴼ, 21.18ᴼ, 30.71ᴼ, 31.58ᴼ, 33.20ᴼ, 35.92ᴼ, 39.14ᴼ, 41.86ᴼ, 45.86ᴼ, 45.33ᴼ and 56.35ᴼ. These peaks can be matched with the standard XRD pattern of dypingite crystalline form of magnesium carbonate (JCPDS Card No. 23-1218). However, there is a slight shift in peaks due to the presence of PMMA in the precursor phase. The XRD pattern of synthesized MgO nanoparticles after calcination of PMMA/MgCO3 is composed of 2θ values at 31.34ᴼ, 36.78ᴼ, 42.73ᴼ, 45.08ᴼ and 62.17ᴼ (Fig. 1 (b)). These peaks reveal the presence of periclase crystalline form of MgO (JCPDS Card No. 75-1525). As calculated from the Debye-Scherrer formula, the average crystallite size of MgO nanoparticles is 42 nm. SEM images of precursor particles and final MgO product are shown in Fig. 2. Spherical nanoparticles of dypingite embedded in PMMA polymer chains are clearly observed in SEM image of the precursor particles (Fig. 2 (a)). The TGA result further confirms the presence of PMMA and MgCO3 in the composite (Fig. S1, in supplementary data). These dypingite particles have been grown in spaces of polymer chains including pockets and voids. Therefore, the further growth of dypingite particles has been avoided by PMMA chains. Well sorted spherical MgO nanoparticles have been obtained by calcination of precursor as observed in SEM image (Fig. 2 (b)). The particle size distribution of MgO nanoparticles was
determined using SEM images by selecting 110 grains in images randomly. The highest particle size distribution is obtained in the range of 151 - 200 nm. However, particles in the distribution over 251 nm seem to be agglomerations of MgO nanoparticles. 3.2. Physico-chemical properties of chitosan/MgO nanocomposites 3.2.1. Tensile properties Typical stress-strain curves and ultimate tensile strength (σ) of chitosan nanocomposites are illustrated in Fig. 3 (a) and (b), respectively. Statistical analysis (ANOVA together with Tukey’s Post Hoc test) revealed that there is a statistically significant difference (P < 0.05) between the means of σ among (i) 0 and 5 (w/w %) and (ii) 5 and 10 (w/w %) of MgO compositions. The addition of MgO into chitosan improved the strength of the material significantly. For instance, σ increased by 86% and 26 % with addition of 5 and 10 (w/w %) of MgO, respectively compared to that of pure chitosan films. This significant improvement could be attributed to the stronger interfacial interaction between the hydroxyl and amine groups of chitosan with MgO via hydrogen bonding. The interfacial interaction is further discussed in the “Chemical Properties” section. σ of chitosan nanocomposites with 5 (w/w %) is better than 10 (w/w %) due to the differences in degree of dispersion of MgO within the chitosan matrix. When there are agglomerated nanoparticles, the stress concentration is considerably high around the aggregates and the material will be easily ruptured under applied force (R. T. De Silva, Pasbakhsh, Goh, & Mishnaevsky Jr, 2014). According to the fracture surface morphology (Fig. 4), well embedded and dispersed MgO nanoparticles can be seen in chitosan nanocomposites with 5 (w/w %) compared to 10 (w/w %) composition (Fig. 4 (a) vs (b), aggregated MgO nanoparticles are marked in arrows and circles). A relatively high amount of micro-voids and pores can be seen in 10 (w/w %) compared to 5 (w/w %) composition as a result of removal of MgO from the matrix under tensile loading (Fig. 4 (a) vs (b)). The presence of such micro-voids and pores could be attributed to the weaker interfacial interaction at higher MgO loadings. σ of pure chitosan films is 22.1 ± 2.3 MPa, which is within the range of σ of pure chitosan films from 4 - 70 MPa, reported elsewhere (de Britto & de Assis, 2007; R. De Silva et al., 2013; Wan, Creber, Peppley, & Bui, 2003). This variation of σ of pure chitosan could be due to the differences in molecular weight of chitosan, degree of deacetylation and composite preparation procedure. Furthermore, tensile stress at fracture (σf) of chitosan nanocomposites also followed a similar trend as σ (Fig. 3 (b)), where σf improved by 69 and 34.5 % by incorporating 5 and 10 (w/w %) of MgO due to the aforementioned reasons.
Correlation between MgO nanoparticles loading and the elastic modulus (E) are analogues to σ results of chitosan nanocomposites (Fig. 3 (c)). Statistical results revealed that there is a significant difference (ANOVA, P < 0.05) between means of E among (i) 0 and 5 (w/w %) and (ii) 5 and 10 (w/w %). E increased by 38 % and 27 % with addition of 5 and 10 (w/w %) of MgO into chitosan matrix and this improvement is due to the enhanced rigidity of the polymer chains resulting from the reinforcing effect of the nano-fillers. Improvement in E at the optimum MgO loading is higher than for those chitosan nanocomposites reinforced with both ZnO and Ag (Youssef et al., 2015). As a result of improved structural rigidity, elongation at break (ɛ) of chitosan nanocomposites has decreased with addition of MgO (Fig. 3 (d)). For instance, ɛ decreased from 5.5% (pure chitosan) to 4.8% and 4.1% with the addition of 5 and 10 (w/w %) of MgO, respectively. ANOVA results revealed that there is no statistically significant difference of means of ɛ between pure chitosan films and nanocomposites. ɛ of pure chitosan films depend on the leftover solvent amount (depends on the drying condition) in the films after those are being synthesised by the solution casting method and entrapped solvent act as a plasticizer (Rhim, Mohanty, Singh, & Ng, 2006). Although the scope of this study is not on the effect of left over solvent of chitosan films on its mechanical properties, a brief discussion on this matter is given in Section S-2 (in Supplementary Document). Nevertheless, ɛ of chitosan/MgO nanocomposite films might limit its applications in the packaging industry where elasticity is required, but it can be overcome by incorporating different plasticizers such as glycerol (Lavorgna, Piscitelli, Mangiacapra, & Buonocore, 2010) and fatty acids (Srinivasa, Ramesh, & Tharanathan, 2007) in order to enhance the ductility of chitosan films. Although, MgO reinforced chitosan films exhibited improved mechanical properties, further research has to be carried out in order to compete with commodity packaging materials such as polyethylene terephthalate (PET) (E=2.0-2.5 GPa), polypropylene (E=1.5-2.0 GPa) and polystyrene (E=3-5 GPa) (Matusik, Stodolak, & Bahranowski, 2011). 3.2.2. Chemical properties FTIR spectra of chitosan/MgO nanocomposites are shown in Fig. 5. Main functional groups of chitosan such as vibration of OH groups at 3359 cm-1 and 3293 cm-1, C-H bond (CH3) at 2923 cm-1, carbonyl bonds of amide groups (C=O-NHR) at 1680 cm-1, bending vibration of methylene groups at 1375 cm-1, amine groups at 1550 - 1590 cm-1 and asymmetric vibration of C=O at 1154 cm-1 are evident in the chitosan/MgO nanocomposites (Paluszkiewicz et al., 2011; Pranoto, Rakshit, & Salokhe, 2005), suggesting that the polymer structure is preserved after fabrication of nanocomposite films. Moreover, vibration bands denote to acetic acid are
not prominent in the films as a result of neutralizing chitosan films during the synthesis (more discussion on this is given in the supplementary document (section S-4)). As illustrated in Fig. 5, the vibration band at 3293 cm-1 which corresponds to the hydroxyl groups of chitosan has shifted to 3286 cm-1 and 3283 cm-1 with addition of 5 and 10 (w/w %) of MgO, respectively (Inset 1, Fig. 5). Furthermore, amine groups of chitosan at 1576 cm-1 have shifted to 1569 cm-1 in both compositions of chitosan/MgO nanocomposites (Inset 2, Fig. 5). Similar shifts in vibrational bands of amine groups of chitosan with other metal oxides have been reported elsewhere (El Kadib, Primo, Molvinger, Bousmina, & Brunel, 2011; Frindy, el Kadib, Lahcini, Primo, & García, 2015). These shifts lead the postulation that the hydroxyl groups and amine groups of chitosan could interact with MgO via hydrogen bonding. This enhanced interfacial interaction between MgO and chitosan facilitates effective stress transfer from the matrix to filler under tensile loading, leading to the improved mechanical properties (σ and E) as observed. X-ray diffraction patterns of chitosan nanocomposite films in Fig. 6 consist of main peaks of MgO (2θ ≈ 40°, 50° and 62°) and that confirms the presence of MgO nanoparticles. The main peak of chitosan (2θ ≈ 18°) remained unchanged with the addition of MgO and that suggests the incorporation of MgO did not change the crystallinity of chitosan. Hence it can be postulated that MgO is a non-nucleating agent towards chitosan and the influence of change in crystallinity on mechanical properties is minimal. 3.2.3. Thermal properties Thermal stability of chitosan nanocomposites are illustrated in Fig. 7. The first mass loss at around 100 ˚C could be attributed to the removal of absorbed moisture and left over solvent (acetic acid), while the second mass loss at 200 - 300 ˚C could occur due to the thermal decomposition of amine and -CH2OH groups of chitosan and the third mass loss at 525 - 650 ˚C could be due to the degradation of glucosamine ring (Martínez-Camacho et al., 2010). Addition of MgO has significantly improved the thermal stability of chitosan films. For instance, at 50 % mass loss the degradation temperature of pure chitosan film is 325 ˚C and it has shifted to 450 ˚C and 529 ˚C with addition of 5 and 10 (w/w %) of MgO, which is a 27 % and 37 % improvement, respectively. Similarly, degradation temperature at all mass losses has increased with addition of MgO compared to that of the pure chitosan films (Table S2, in supplementary documents). These enhancements could be attributed to the high thermal stability of MgO (thermal decomposition starts around 2800 ˚C) as well as the homogeneous distribution of MgO. Dispersion of MgO within the chitosan matrix could act as a barrier to
hinder the diffusion of thermally degraded products of chitosan, which results in an effective delay in mass transport. Flame retardancy of chitosan films and its nanocomposites was also investigated using the glow wire test. All chitosan composites satisfied the V-0 rating according to the UL-94 industrial standard, where the flame extinguished within 30 seconds after the ignition without any dripping behaviour. UL-94 Vertical burn test revealed that the chitosan/MgO nanocomposites burnt at a slower rate compared to that of pure chitosan films. Pure chitosan films burnt at 0.2 cm/s, while nanocomposites with 5 and 10 (w/w %) MgO burnt at 0.073 cm/s. These observations are in good agreement with the TGA data. 3.2.4. UV-shielding properties and water vapour transmission rate (WVTR) UV absorption of the nanocomposites is illustrated in Fig. 8. Pure chitosan films have a very limited UV absorption compared to that of chitosan nanocomposites with MgO. For instance, at 300 nm the absorption of chitosan nanocomposites with 5 and 10 (w/w %) MgO is 42 % and 112 % higher than the absorption of pure chitosan films, respectively. These results indicate that the UV transmission through chitosan nanocomposites is significantly reduced compared to that of pure chitosan films, due to the UV-shielding ability of MgO nanoparticles. A similar observation has been reported in the literature where UV protection for polyacrylonitrile matrix was obtained by incorporating MgO nanoparticles (Dadvar et al., 2011).
Water vapour transmission rate (WVTR) of pure chitosan films yielded to be 172.3 g/m2.h and it has drastically reduced by 27% (127 g/m2.h) and 32% (117.3 g/m2.h) with the addition of 5 and 10 (w/w %) of MgO nanoparticles, respectively. These improvements could be attributed to the presence of dispersed MgO nanoparticles within the matrix which would act as a barrier to hinder the diffusion of water vapour through the nanocomposites. Furthermore, MgO could absorb hydroxyl groups to form Mg(OH)2 during the water vapour permeation. These improved moisture barrier properties of MgO incorporated chitosan nanocopmposites would certainly help to increase the shelf life of food in packaging applications.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text:
Chitosan/MgO nanocomposite films were fabricated using the solution casting method by varying MgO concentration from 0 – 10 (w/w %). Spherical shaped MgO nanoparticles with
a diameter of 150 - 200 nm were synthesised using a novel in-situ method by heat-treating magnesium carbonate/poly (methyl methacrylate) (PMMA) composite precursor. Mechanical properties of chitosan was significantly improved with addition of MgO and 5 (w/w %) concentration yielded to be the optimum composition to reinforce chitosan. Tensile strength and elastic modulus of chitosan nanocomposites with 5 (w/w %) MgO improved by 86 % and 38 %, respectively. According to the FTIR studies, it was postulated that the improvements in mechanical properties could be due to the interfacial interaction between hydroxyl and amine groups of MgO via hydrogen bonding. Improvements of mechanical properties at high MgO loadings (10 (w/w %)) were insignificant due to the aggregation of MgO particles. TGA revealed that the thermal stability of chitosan films improved remarkably. For instance, at 50 % mass loss the degradation temperature of pure chitosan film shifted to higher temperatures by 27 % and 37 % with the addition of 5 and 10 (w/w %) of MgO, respectively. Furthermore, chitosan/MgO nanocomposites exhibited flame retardant properties and satisfied V-0 rating according U-94 standard; chitosan/MgO nanocomposite films burnt at a much slower rate (63 % slower) compared to that of pure chitosan. Chitosan nanocomposites with MgO nanoparticles also showed superior UV-shielding and moisture barrier properties. The fabricated chitosan/MgO nanocomposite films with enhanced physico-chemical properties can be used as a potential packaging material.

sections.heading: Acknowledgments
sections.text: We would like to thank Dr. Nicola Gurusinghe, Dr. Nuwan de Silva and Ms. Jayani Senevirathne for their valuable guidance and contribution.

Main functional groups of chitosan such as vibration of OH groups at 3359 cm and 3293 cm, C-H bond (CH3) at 2923 cm, carbonyl bonds of amide groups (C=O-NHR) at 1680 cm, bending vibration of methylene groups at 1375 cm, amine groups at 1550 - 1590 cm and asymmetric vibration of C=O at 1154 cm are evident in the chitosan/MgO nanocomposites (Paluszkiewicz et al., 2011; Pranoto, Rakshit, & Salokhe, 2005), suggesting that the polymer structure is preserved after fabrication of nanocomposite films.

metadata.abstractText: Chitosan nanocomposite thin films were fabricated by incorporating MgO nanoparticles to significantly improve its physical properties for potential packaging applications. A novel insitu method was developed to synthesise spherical shaped MgO nanoparticles by heat-
metadata.creator: Elsevier
